Genres are a common language in this regard. They're guides to facilitate decision making.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet:
And for writers: If you write for a themed antho, don't make the cut, fret not!
1. Sit on it for a while and avoid the immediate torrent over the other rejectees hitting slush piles.
2. Rewrite and change the theme if you can.
cont...

B. Explosion.
C. Egg.

I stand by this, even for period romance, erotica, and nonfiction.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet:
Following the immoral actions of an extreme horror writer a few months ago, I'm again seeing posts that extreme horror people are all violent, perverts, and sexual predators. 

I've never met a friendlier and mutually supportive bunch than in the extreme end. Cont...

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet:
What is not okay is to attack others in the genre for what they enjoy or write. Light horror readers are not wimps, extreme horror readers are not sickos.

We're a community of diverse tastes, and I think this is wonderful. Cont...

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet:
For some it doesn't take much to shock, to frighten...to even offend.

Others needs more to get a gut reaction, needing material aimed to disgust and appall to get any emotional connection.

Again...and that's all okay. Cont...

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet:
Just a note. On this. Again.

People's emotional reaction to horror lit is a spectrum. A bell curve, I'd say. The majority of horror readers enjoying the meaty middle between extreme and light.

And that's okay. Cont...

I do therapy and love it, worrying that I shouldn't do research.

Went to court once.

I had paid my lease in full, handed back keys, cosigned end of rental on that date.

Landlord took me to court for weeks of missing rent. On the agreement, he'd scribbled out the date, wrote another for weeks later.

Judge accepted it as reasonable.

The secret to productivity...is time.

Something you've been putting off? Set a timer. You'll donate an hour of your time to it. Just an hour! Get a coffee, some music, and go for it until you hear the beeps.

You might not finish, but you'll be closer.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 10.Have mental health contacts close by, such as Beyond Blue, The Samaritans, etc. Immediate help in times of crisis in the comfort of your own home. Find them sooner rather than later and keep them close to hand. Listening is what we‚Äôre here for. Tell us what‚Äôs going on.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 9.Worry procrastination: Pick a time that‚Äôs convenient and not close to bedtime. This is your worry time. Watch the news and worry like mad over the world for a few minutes. Same time tomorrow. If you start to worry before then, verbally remind yourself it isn‚Äôt worry time yet.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 8.Self-care. Try your best to eat well, sleep, exercise, relax. Do what you can to continue doing activities you enjoy, such as reading. Need a new horrifying read? (Sorry, author‚Äôs gotta eat too). Movies. Games. Dust off the ol‚Äô Monopoly board. I‚Äôm the little sports car.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 7.Keep perspective. What is happening right now? We can get through this. No sign of zombies yet. If we run out of toilet paper, there‚Äôs a hose out the back.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 6.Identify triggers. What is it about the current situation that‚Äôs causing the most worry? Can we avoid this (turn off the news) or reduce it (enjoy garden to reduce cabin fever)? If that‚Äôs difficult, self-care and problem solving might provide temporary distraction.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 5. Social help: You‚Äôre reading this, you‚Äôre online. Join conversations. Look into those groups you were thinking about. Importantly, ask for advice from trusted sources rather than struggle alone. Millions are going through this experience. Share your story. Listen to others.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 4.Problem solving, no matter how small, reduces stress. Create a list of quick, manageable jobs you need to do. How many can you tick off this afternoon? Dishes, empty bin, tidy lounge. Might take half an hour. Lovely. Now go and do yours.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 3.Avoiding meta-worry, which is worrying about worrying. This is a challenging and strange time. Worrying is a completely natural and appropriate response! Worrying about how you‚Äôre reacting can provide another tier of distress on your anxiety cake.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 2.Mindfulness. The aim is to keep your mind in the moment, not running off into a future of ‚Äòwhat ifs‚Äô. Many guided mindful exercises on YouTube. However, this can take practice to get ‚Äòin the zone‚Äô.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: 1.Breathe in for 4s, hold for 1s, breath out for 4s. Once you find the rhythm, try to exhale over 5s. This will help to slow breathing and heart rate, and can keep panic/anxiety attacks at bay. Gives your mind a chance to grab the wheel back before the body takes over completely.

name: D.I.Russell
description: No one's favourite horror author. Proud ASD individual. Working on PhD in health and clinical Œ® (somehow) and finishing clinical practice.
tweet: After witnessing an increase in general anxiety regarding #coronavirus, thought I‚Äôd put my training to good use and list 10 tips to manage worry for our current predicament. Tried to keep it light-hearted, and I hope it helps anyone experiencing heightened anxiety at the moment.
